DataElement.preferredName: Visceral Lesion Present Indicator Anatomic Site
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents whether or not a visceral lesion is present and the anatomic location.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Of, or relating to, or affecting the internal organs._A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part._Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time._A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Visceral; of, or relating to, or affecting the internal organs.:(LEE-zhun) An area of abnormal tissue change.

Concepts.definition: Of, or relating to, or affecting the internal organs.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
